entry.title: Development of ETL pipelines
entry.summary: In today's world, we're surrounded by systems and tools that generate data. These data contain a vast amount of information,…
entry.content:
In today's world, we're surrounded by systems and tools that generate data. These data contain a vast amount of information, which can help us understand important processes, confirm or disprove our beliefs or classify and predict outcomes.

What is Extract, Transform and Load (ETL)?

A common challenge with transforming data into powerful insights is that the data often comes from different sources and in different formats, making it challenging to use as it is. This is where developing an Extract, Transform and Load (ETL) pipeline can come in handy. By linking data from different sources and transforming it according to rules relevant for your business, you can build a solid fundament for your reporting, business intelligence or statistical/machine learning modelling.

What are the benefits of having proper ETL pipelines?

There are many ways in which having clean, well-structured and easily accessible data may benefit your organisation:

Here's how having proper data collection and cleaning processes can bring value to your organisation:

  • Enhanced decision making: clean data leads to more accurate analysis, which can improve decision-making.
  • Improved operational efficiency: clean data can streamline business processes, removing redundancies and silo work and ensuring that a single source of truth is available in the organisation, leading to an increased efficiency reliability.
  • Increased customer acquisition and retention: accurate data can help in better understanding the customers, leading to more effective marketing strategies and increased customer acquisition
  • Improved talent acquisition and retention: similarly to product and customer data, data on your talent acquisition, employee experience, remuneration and career development can help you attract and retain the talent your organisation needs to perform at its best.
  • Increased revenue: with improved decision-making and customer acquisition, companies can see an increase in revenue.
  • Increased employee productivity: with access to clean and reliable data, employees can be more productive as they don‚Äôt have to spend time dealing with inaccurate data.
  • Minimised waste of time and money: cleaning data helps in avoiding mistakes that could cost the company in terms of time and money.

In summary, ETL and data cleaning are integral parts of handling data in any organisational context. They help to ensure that the data is accurate, reliable, and in a format that is easy to analyse, leading to more informed decision-making and improved business outcomes.

If you are interested in automating or improving your existing data flows or if you need assistance setting up access to external data sources, feel free to reach out at kirilboyanovbg@gmail.com for a free, no-strings-attached 30 minutes meeting where we can discuss your needs in more detail.

entry.title: Fra data til indsigter
entry.summary: üëã Hej, jeg hedder Kiril, og velkommen til MindGraph: mit eget konsulentsfirma, specialiseret i at hj√¶lpe dig med at omdanne…
entry.content:
üëã Hej, jeg hedder Kiril, og velkommen til MindGraph: mit eget konsulentsfirma, specialiseret i at hj√¶lpe dig med at omdanne dine data til¬† indsigter, som du kan handle p√•. Jeg br√¶nder for at finde sammenh√¶nge i data samt bist√• beslutningstagere med praktiske, databaserede anbefalinger.

F√• hj√¶lp med dit projekt

Uanset om det drejer sig om at definere og afgr√¶nse projekter, skabe ETL pipelines og BI rapporter eller udvikle pr√¶diktive modeller, mit kendskab spreder sig over en bred vifte af datarelaterede opgaver.

Her er nogle af de omr√•der, hvorp√• jeg kan bidrage:

Udforsk dine datas potentiale

Data er n√¶sten aldrig perfekt, men det skal ikke forhindre os i at finde v√¶rdifulde indsigter i dem. Ved at kombinere din dom√¶neviden og min dataekspertise kan vi teste dine hypoteser i praksis, fremh√¶ve vigtige konklusioner og lave konkrete anbefalinger, som du kan handle p√•.

Kontakt mig venligst p√• info@mindgraph.dk for et gratis uforpligtende m√∏de p√• 30 minutter, hvor vi kan diskutere dine behov og vores mulige samarbejde i forbindelse med dit projekt.

Tag et kig p√• hvad MindGraph kan g√∏re for dig

I disse projekter har jeg nemlig v√¶ret med til alt fra start til slut, dvs. at jeg b√•de har indsalmet, renset og analyseret p√• dataene samt formidlet de endelige indisgter i menneskesprog. Jeg arbejder hele tiden p√• nye projekter, og du er altid velkommen til at tjekke den fulde liste for at finde flere sp√¶ndende ting!

entry.title: Contact
entry.summary: If you have a potential project you'd like to discuss, we can arrange a free 30 minutes online meeting where…
entry.content:
If you have a potential project you'd like to discuss, we can arrange a free 30 minutes online meeting where we can talk about your needs and requirements and where we can align our expectations.

  • Email: if you'd like to make an inquiry, it's best to drop me a message at info@mindgraph.dk.
  • LinkedIn: you're also welcome to contact me via a private message. You can find my LinkedIn profile here.
  • GitHub: my GitHub page contains demos of some of the projects I've worked on in my spare time. Feel free to explore and get an idea of what I'd be able to do for you.

entry.title: From data to insight
entry.summary: üëã Hello, my name's Kiril and welcome to MindGraph: my private consultancy specialised in helping you leverage your data by…
entry.content:
üëã Hello, my name's Kiril and welcome to MindGraph: my private consultancy specialised in helping you leverage your data by transforming it into actionable insights. I am passionate about finding patterns in the data and providing decision-makers with practical, data-driven recommendations.

Get help with your project

Whether it's scoping projects, creating data ETL pipelines and BI reports, or developing predictive models, my expertise spans a broad spectrum of data-related services.

Here are some of the areas I cover:

Unlock the potential of your data

Data is almost never perfect, but that doesn't deter me from using it to extract valuable insights. By combining your domain knowledge and my data expertise, we can test your hypotheses in practice, highlight important conclusions and recommend actions to address pressing challenges.

Please reach out to me at info@mindgraph.dk for a free, no-strings-attached 30 minutes meeting where we can discuss your needs and do some initial project scoping.

Take a peek at what MindGraph could do for you

To see how I've applied my skills in real-life situations, feel free to explore some of the projects I've worked on in the past:

In these projects, I've taken care of the whole process from sourcing and cleaning the data to analysing it and communicating the insights in layman terms. I constantly work on new projects, so feel free to check back the full list later for some more awesome stuff!

entry.title: Services
entry.summary: During my 5+ years of full-time experience, I've worked on a wide variety of tasks spanning from data collection, transformation…
entry.content:
During my 5+ years of full-time experience, I've worked on a wide variety of tasks spanning from data collection, transformation and analysis to presenting insights and onboarding users to interactive tools and reports. The various roles I've held have thought me the importance of relating data to a business context and designing products that are tailored to the end user's needs, also when that user is a non-technical person.

Throughout my experience, I've worked with many different kinds of data, including personal data, macroeconomic and political data, data on pricing, survey/cross-sectional data and time series data.

Below, you can read more about which areas MindGraph can help you in:

  • Project scoping üéØ
  • Building an ETL data pipeline ü™Ç
  • Designing interactive BI reports üìä
  • Running statistical analysis and hypothesis testing ‚öñÔ∏è
  • Building predictive statistical/ML models üîÆ
  • Onboarding and training of non-technical people üßë‚Äçüè´
    • Evaluating and optimising the use of your data-driven insights üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
    • Introducing leaders to technical terms and concepts üßë‚Äçüíª
  • Need help with your data/analytics project? üßó

Project scoping üéØ

Whether it comes down to conducting a one-off analytics project, building a data pipeline or designing an interactive business intelligence solution, I can help you translate your business needs into a project specification. Together, we can define the scope of the final product, estimate the resources needed to achieve your goal, identify opportunities for improvement and mitigate any potential risks.

Project scoping may be related to:

  • Setting up a data extract, transform and load (ETL) pipeline
  • Designing a Business Intelligence (BI)/reporting solution
  • Running an analytics project involving either statistical analysis or machine learning (ML)

Click here to learn more about project scoping and its benefits.

Building an ETL data pipeline ü™Ç

To be able to transform data into powerful insights, it is necessary to set up a proper¬†Extract, Transform and Load (ETL) pipeline. By linking data from different sources and transforming it according to rules relevant for your business, you can build a solid fundament for your reporting, business intelligence or statistical/machine learning modelling.

Building a data pipeline may consist of:

  • Collecting data from structured sources (e.g. databases, cloud storage solutions, survey tools, software that generates data or other curated datasets)
  • Collecting data from unstructured sources (e.g. web scraping)
  • Data clean-up (e.g. restructuring the data, repairing logical errors, etc.)
  • Applying business logic to the data to make it truly meaningful
  • Combining data from different sources and/or building a data model
  • Publishing the output data to a final storage solution so they can be reused across projects (e.g. a database, cloud storage, network drive, etc.)

Click here to learn more about ETL pipelines and their benefits.

Designing interactive BI reports üìä

The way to unlocking the potential of your data often starts with getting to know your data and what better way to understand your data than to visualise it in a way that's meaningful to your organisation? Whether you want to track real-time metrics or follow important developments in quarterly or annual KPIs, identify difference between different categories of products, customers or employees, an interactive, automatically updated report can facilitate you in achieving your goals.

Designing a business intelligence (BI) solution may include:

  • Building an ETL data pipeline and/or a data model to facilitate data import
  • Performing additional calculations to support data visualisation
  • Creating different data visualisations and adding different functionalities to the report (e.g. the ability to use filters and slicers on the data or change the metrics shown on the charts)
  • Designing and testing the user interface (UI) of the report in collaboration with end users
  • Documenting any calculations and assumptions made in the model
  • Onboarding end users to ensure they can make the best possible use of the new product

Click here to learn more about BI reporting and its benefits.

Running statistical analysis and hypothesis testing ‚öñÔ∏è

While data visualisation is a great way to start exploring the potential of your data, a chart is seldom sufficient to tell you the story behind what you see on it. To dig deeper and ensure that the insights you're getting have a solid backing, it is often useful to do some sort of hypothesis testing or study the impact of different factors on the metric you're interested in explaining. With the right kind of statistical analysis, you will not only be able to discern between apparent and real patterns but also measure important differences and effects observed in the data.

Running a statistical analysis may include:

  • Data collection and preparation for use in the analysis
  • Defining and testing hypotheses
  • Explaining correlations and interrelationships in your data
  • Identifying outlier observations in your data
  • Measuring the impact of certain factors on a given outcome (e.g. how many additional sales can be generated by giving a discount or what the likelihood that a customer will cancel their subscription is based on their recent behaviour)
  • Summing up on the conclusions and communicating them to the relevant stakeholders

Click here to learn more about how statistical analysis can be used in practice to solve real-world problems.

Building predictive statistical/ML models üîÆ

Data-mature organisations use a mixture of approaches to extract the most value from their data and stay competitive. With the recent explosion in generative AI, the edge that applying methods more sophisticated than traditional statistical analysis has been getting the spotlight. In reality, both machine learning (ML) and traditional statistics can be useful when it comes to building predictive models. The choice of whether to use one thing or the other will often depend on your circumstances, such as the quality and quantity of the data you have available. Either way, having a predictive model at your disposal can be a powerful tool to supercharge your decision-making.

Building predictive models may include:

  • Defining the model's input and output variables
  • Data collection and preparation for use in the analysis
  • Training, testing and optimising different kinds of algorithms to improve model accuracy
  • Using the optimised model to generate predictions for the outcome variable
  • Setting up a recurrent model training and predictions generation

Click here to learn more about predictive modelling and its benefits.

Onboarding and training of non-technical people üßë‚Äçüè´

If you find yourself in a situation where either you or someone else in your company feels unable to use the outputs of your analytics/data science team, then you may benefit from a proper introduction to those tools and the concepts they build upon.

Evaluating and optimising the use of your data-driven insights üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

You may have an excellent data set-up at your organisation and use the most cutting-edge technologies to derive insights but if people are not able to use these tools or understand how you've arrived at your conclusion, you may not be using your data to your full potential. Explainability is a particular challenge for machine learning (ML) models but can also extend to interactive reporting tools or even statistical analysis, where data and results may easily be misinterpreted.

With the right kind of communication and user onboarding, you can minimise the risk that your work may end up unused or, perhaps even worse, used in the wrong way, leading to making harmful decisions for your organisation, its customers and employees.

Introducing leaders to technical terms and concepts üßë‚Äçüíª

Alternatively, you may find yourself in charge of a highly technical team even though you may not necessarily have the same background as them. Your excellent leadership skills will go a long way in ensuring the team has the right inputs to accomplish their goals, but you may feel a bit uneasy about all the unfamiliar concepts they casually throw around you. If you feel like you'd like to learn more about the tools your team is using but are limited on time or fear falling down the trap of getting bogged down by all the details, you may benefit from a proper introduction to the tools and concepts used in modern data management.

Whether you'd like to know more about the basics of programming using R or Python, dive deeper into the obvious and more obscure functionalities offered by Excel or Power BI, MindGraph can support you with getting the right amount of technical knowledge needed to better understand and support your team.

Need help with your data/analytics project? üßó

Please reach out to me at info@mindgraph.dk for a free, no-strings-attached 30 minutes meeting where we can discuss your needs and do some initial project scoping.

entry.title: About
entry.summary: MindGraph started in 2024 as a part-time endeavour, a place to collect various projects I've worked on in the past…
entry.content:
MindGraph started in 2024 as a part-time endeavour, a place to collect various projects I've worked on in the past and to explore the possibilities of partnering with other companies and individuals who are interested in leveraging data to better understand and act on what's on their mind.

On this page, I describe the mission and vision of Mindsight. If you're interested in the details, you can explore my areas of expertise here.

Mission

My mission is to contribute to a better world by facilitating a deeper understanding of the patterns and phenomena that shape our reality. I am committed to providing decision-makers with practical recommendations based on a solid data foundation. By harnessing my curiosity, dedication, and perseverance, I tackle real-world data challenges, extract meaningful insights, and communicate them in a user-friendly, accessible manner.

Vision

I envision a future where data-driven insights empower decision-makers at all levels, fostering informed choices that lead to a better, more equitable world. To arrive there, I believe we need to reshape the way working with data and analytics is perceived, transforming it from a complex, challenging endeavour into something more relatable and accessible for the average human being. Data-driven insights can help us change the world for the better - provided that we are all on board with the story the data is trying to tell us.

entry.title: World happiness study
entry.summary: Do you know what the world‚Äôs happiest country is? (Spoiler alert: it‚Äôs somewhere in the Nordics.) Each year, the World…
entry.content:
Do you know what the world‚Äôs happiest country is? (Spoiler alert: it‚Äôs somewhere in the Nordics.) Each year, the World Happiness Report (WHR) gives an account of the state of happiness around the world. More often than not, its findings are not that surprising: highly developed countries with stable political systems are on top, while poor and war-torn countries are relegated to the bottom.

In this project (which I worked on between April 2023 - January 2024), I delved into the data to explore how happiness scores have evolved over time and identify the key factors that impact national happiness. Then, I used this knowledge to predict countries‚Äô happiness scores for 2023-2024 before the WHR has even collected the data! Below, I present some of my findings but I strongly encourage you to download my infographic so as not to miss on any of the insights.

Happiness is on a downwards trajectory

People around the world are now less happy than they were roughly two decades ago, with global happiness showing a decline of 14% in the period 2005-2022, as shown on the chart below:

The¬†the largest decline in happiness was observed in countries which have had very dire economic circumstances and/or military conflicts such as Afghanistan, Lebanon and Venezuela, while the largest improvement was seen in several African and Eastern European countries.

Happiness reflects development and governance

National happiness is largely defined by how well developed and how well governed a country is. Accounting for various economic, political, social, environmental and health-related factors, it is possible to explain up to 74% of the differences in happiness scores between countries over time.

I arrived at this conclusion by testing a series of ridge-regression models, where the best fitting model contained a total of 27 factors.¬†Out of these, the ones with the strongest relative impact on global happiness were GDP per capita, female unemployment rate, access to electricity, health expenditure per capita and corruption. Other factors with a sizeable effect on happiness are shown below:

Future happiness can be predicted accurately

Over the past 17 years, Denmark has consistently ranked among the top 3 happiest countries, a feat it has achieved an impressive 16 times. Many of the other countries which appear on top of the list have also consistenly ranked high on happiness across time. Given these strong historical trends, I decided to explore how the state of happiness is going to look for in the next couple of years, assuming the underlying factors that determine national happiness remain unchanged.

To do so, I developed a machine learning model (random forest) to generate the predictions.The model was trained on all years except for the most recent year with available happiness score (2022) and was optimised to increase its accuracy. The input variables included in the model, which were selected based on the ridge regression analysis, did not originally have values in future time periods, so those were derived by projecting historical trends into the future. Assuming country-level historical trends remain valid in the forecasting period, the model should be able to predict national happiness scores with an accuracy of up to 96%.

According to this model, the top 10 happiest countries in 2023 should be:

  1. Finland (predicted happiness score: 7.65)
  2. Denmark (7.61)
  3. Switzerland (7.43*)
  4. Iceland (7.43)
  5. Norway (7.43)
  6. Sweden(7.28)
  7. Netherlands (7.27)
  8. Luxembourg (7.17)
  9. Austria (7.16)
  10. New Zealand (7.05)

Similarly, the top 10 happiest countries in 2024 should be:

  1. Denmark (predicted happiness score: 7.62)
  2. Finland (7.57)
  3. Switzerland (7.40)
  4. Iceland (7.38)
  5. Norway (7.28)
  6. Luxembourg (7.19)
  7. Austria (7.15)
  8. Netherlands (7.14)
  9. Sweden (7.06)
  10. Australia (7.02)

Of course, those are just projections based on the assumptions that historical trends for happiness score and its underlying factors will continue into the future. Therefor, it‚Äôll be exciting to see how accurate these predictions prove to be once the actual rankings are released!

üîéüìà Explore the full analysis on the project's GitHub page.

üìäüìñ Download the infographic with all the insights here.

* Note: the numbers in here have been rounded off to two decimals but in reality, more decimal points are available and the countries have been sorted according to the original, unrounded numbers.

Page cover image source: www.pixabay.com

entry.title: Rentals in the Greater Copenhagen area
entry.summary: If you've ever been looking for a place to stay in the Greater Copenhagen area (Stork√∏benhavn), you probably know that…
entry.content:
If you've ever been looking for a place to stay in the Greater Copenhagen area (Stork√∏benhavn), you probably know that the struggle is real. With limited supply and high pricing, finding an accommodation can be a challenging task. Prompted by my personal curiousity on the subject, I decided to look into the data to figure out what is generally available for rent, how much it costs as well as which factors influence the price. In this article, I would like to share some of my findings with you, though I encourage you to download my infographic to get all insights.

Disclaimer: Please note that the conclusions and recommendations presented below are as of February 2023. While I expect these to remain more or less stable due to the structural character of the rental market, some changes may occur.

What's available on the market?

This analysis is based on advertisements scapred from the Danish website www.boligportal.dk, where landlords post about accommodations they have available for rent. These can range from single rooms to apartments and houses.

As of 21 February 2023, there were just over 3,000 rentals listed in the Greater Copenhagen area (Stork√∏benhavn in Danish). The vast majority of these were apartments (82%) and single rooms (12%). Rooms were mostly located in the city (‚Öî of all rooms), while houses were mostly located in the suburbs (92% of all houses).

Other things worth noting include:

  • Overall, 73% of all accommodations were available for rent for an unlimited time period.
  • When it comes to size, regular houses are the rental type with the largest median area (153 m¬≤), followed by semi-detached houses (120 m¬≤) and apartments (87 m¬≤).
  • If we measure size by the median number of rooms instead, the conclusion is pretty similar, with houses leading (5 rooms), followed by semi-detached (4 rooms) and apartments (3 rooms).
  • Apartments were the type of accommodation most likely to be associate with an unlimited lease duration, while houses were least likely to be available for an unlimited time period, as the chart below shows:

Not sure what‚Äôs reasonable to pay for rent?

Looking at the price of rent per square meter, we see that for the vast majority of accommodations, you‚Äôd be expected to pay between 150-200 kr. per m¬≤. That being said, in some cases the price can be as low as 67 kr. per m¬≤ or as high as 894 kr. per m¬≤. In 75% of all cases, you can furthermore expect to pay below 13.22 kr. per m¬≤ in relation to the monthly fixed acconto payment.

Please note that rent prices differ based on both geographical location and the type of accommodation, as can be seen on the chart below:

Wonder how to save money on rent?

You can use several strategies here. You can either go for a smaller place (if you want to save in absolute terms) or a bigger place (if you want to save in relative terms, given that the price of rent per m¬≤ decreases with size). You can also choose a less central location, for example, by opting not to live in Copenhagen or Frederiksberg, you can save 53 kr. per m¬≤ on average.

Want to live alone?

If you are single or you just want to live by yourself, then you might be better off by renting a one-room apartment (e.g. a studio) rather than going for a single room in a shared accommodation. Based on median price, one-room apartments are 43% cheaper than single rooms. In fact, if we look at the bottom 75% of all one-room apartments, prices will not exceed 245 kr. per square meter, whereas if we look at the bottom 75% of all single rooms, the price per square meter can be as high as 463 kr. (a difference of 89%).

These are insights from my latest spare time project, where I looked into data on 3,000+ privately rented accommodations from the Danish website BoligPortal. You can read more about the project in the linked infographic and go in-depth with the analysis on my GitHub page.

üìäüìñ Download the infographic with all the insights here.

üîéüìà Explore the analysis on the project's GitHub page.

Page cover image source: www.pixabay.com
